displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So they don’t want to, uh, subject you to, you know, have a needle stuck in your bone if it’s not going to be helpful. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so, but the trial requires the tissue, because they’re trying to study how the new drug affects the tissue in some way. So let me, let me look into that, uh, to see if any of the trials allow bone only. The only trials we have for hormonal treatment are with Xtandi right now, uh, not with the other drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, if it looks like you can’t, if it looks like you would fit on the trial, we can talk about them more. If, if it looks like the bone thing is going to eliminate that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that-

Family Member: Right. Doctor: -but I can find out if somebody… Family Member: Was scheduled the same day or something. Doctor: But I assume that’s not the case, but I’ll just double check. Patient: Alright. Family Member: Okay. (sighs) Doctor: No. It’ll be back by tomorrow. Family Member: Okay. And that won’t change the course of what you recommend anyway? Doctor: It’s either gonna be zero or like point one or two so um. Family Member: What if it’s not though? What if it hasn’t gone down that much? Does that lead us to believe…? Doctor: It’s still not gonna change what we’re gonna do. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go. Family Member: February fifth till – Doctor: Oh yeah, because even if you start in January, it’s monthly, so. Family Member: So February fifth till like the twenty, till like the twenty-second or something. Doctor: Oh that’s fine. That’s fine. Family Member: So we have to schedule that around then. Doctor: Oh yeah, he’ll, trust me, we will hunt you down. He will hunt you down because every time you’re about to get a dose, it’s fifteen thousand dollars a dose.

Patient: Oh yeah but anyway, but anyway uh Dr. B____ the, the, the I think he’s short. I can’t think of his name. Anyway, he told me to talk to him. It’s a Chinese guy that that that denied me, but his boss… Doctor: M____ Pharmacy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or where? Patient: His boss is the short guy. That’s who I’m waiting to talk to. I’m hoping he’ll be here today so that when I leave here today I can talk to him. Doctor: Okay. So we’ll give you the script and then you go there first see if they are willing to. Patient: Tell me what’s going on Dr. B____. That’s what I want to know. What is the – this is the call they’re sending everything Doctor: Let me take a look. Patient: So everything I’m going through man seems like it’s causing this man I mean when they said pain… Doctor: Okay so I looked at. Patient: …when they say pain I’m saying like… Doctor: Okay can I see it? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there. Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Then they, do they attach to the uh to the antibody? Doctor: Well, so it’s not an antibody. Patient: Oh. Its an enzyme, enzyme.. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical.

Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no? Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too. Doctor: Yeah. If he had to. Family Member: But it’s hard to get. Doctor: But for now let’s keep it. Family Member: That’s what I think. We’ve waited a long time. Doctor: Don’t, don’t change anything until we see what the dates fall out to be. Family Member: Fine. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes- Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test.

Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’? Doctor: No!!!! What is your fixation about the lower body parts? (Laughs) Patient: Well then – when you go -- how you gonna get to – how you gonna do the biopsy? You gonna cut me open? Doctor: No! You lay down on the CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They numb up an area right around here or here – Patient: Right. Doctor: Depending on what side. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put a needle through – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Doc They take samples out – Patient: Okay!

Family Member: APS. Patient: She came here actually for one of the world experts on APS. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Which is a blood disorder. Clotting. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: I thought I would mention it ‘cuz I think for her – Doctor: I don’t know enough about that. I’d have to read up about that, but I don’t think it relates. Family Member: For her, it was a really easy fix. Doctor: That’s not a gene on this panel that they did for you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They do more common cancer genes. Family Member: Oh, I see.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Uh, the – we always ask about pain, you know. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, because pain does mean -- pain means we gotta do something now. Family Member: I get it. Doctor: Most people don’t have pain. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But people in the old days, maybe your father, you think about it, you know, um, that was pain that you remember. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Uh. But because of our better therapies, men have less pain. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: He’s got a lot of disease in his bone that there may be that they can’t sense pain. Family Member: Okay. Alright. Yeah. Alright.

Patient: Are you smoking? Come on. Family Member: Whoa wait a minute. Patient: There’s a disconnect you change your… Family Member: Did you see my face? Patient: Probably mine too but uh – but who did we hear routine would be six? Who told us six? Family Member: I don’t know… Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total.

Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: - and the prostate is enlarged. Does it make any sense to remove it? Doctor: No, we wouldn’t operate on it. We would potentially radiate it. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah, I understood that it would not be removed. Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and… Doctor: Well again I’m just getting more data as we’re talking here. Patient: I also sent saliva to do DNA test – Doctor: Uh huh. Patient: - and the thing has said it’s not hereditary. Family Member: That’s the copy. Doctor: Okay, I’ll take a look at it

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. And um basically I will give this consent form and you can take it home to read through. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer. Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: It’s possible that as part of this trial if you decide to look into it more – PAT; Um, hum. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: PSMA stands for prostate-specific membrane antigen. It’s a protein that sits on the cell membrane, on the surface of the cancer cell – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . So it’s possible with that kind of scan we might find more than one spot.

Family Member: …and they cauterized. Doctor: the radiation and it’s cauterized now so I’m thinking that will take care of it. Patient: Yet no polyps, no polyps. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, good. Healthcare Professional: And their advice to hold up on aspirin. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. Doctor: Don’t take it until – but that could probably be temporary as long as the bleeding has stopped you know if a few weeks they may be able to go ahead and restart. Family Member: So would we be completely transferring care downtown then? Doctor: For?
